Histopathology after stereotactic biopsy confirmed a diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma (DIPG) WHO grade IV. Molecular profiling demonstrated an H3‑K27M mutation and a co‑occurring ACVR1 G328V mutation. 

The patient was enrolled in a multi‑center phase II trial (NCT04056995) evaluating the combination of the dopamine receptor D2 antagonist ONC201 (500 mg orally once weekly) with standard focal radiotherapy (54 Gy in 30 fractions). Concurrently, a low‑dose pan‑histone deacetylase inhibitor, panobinostat, was administered at 10 mg/m² orally on days 1, 8, and 15 of each 28‑day cycle. After completing radiotherapy, the patient continued ONC201 monotherapy at the same dose. 

At the 12‑week follow‑up MRI, the T2 hyperintensity demonstrated a 55 % reduction in volume compared with baseline, and contrast enhancement was no longer appreciable. Clinically, the patient’s gait had improved, and diplopia resolved; however, he reported Grade 2 fatigue and occasional mild nausea, which were attributed to panobinostat and managed with supportive care. No Grade ≥ 3 adverse events were recorded. 

The trial protocol specifies that continuation of ONC201 is permitted in the absence of radiographic progression (defined as ≥ 25 % increase in T2‑weighted tumor volume) and in the presence of ≤ Grade 2 treatment‑related toxicity. Discontinuation is mandated if disease progression is observed on MRI or if Grade ≥ 3 toxicity occurs. The investigators also noted that patients achieving ≥ 50 % reduction in tumor volume at 12 weeks are considered “radiographic responders” and are encouraged to remain on therapy for up to 24 months provided safety criteria are met.
